p: We conducted field surveys on Liangzi Island (114°34′26″–114°35′22″ E, 30°16′13″–30°15′22″N) and Qingshan Island (30°16′44″–30 °15′44″E, 114°33′40″– 114°34′20″N), which are both in the centre of Liangzi Lake (a typical shallow lake in the middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze River); the areas of the two islands are 2.2 km 2 and 1.0 km 2, respectively. In the 1980s, A. philoxeroides invaded this area, and it is now prevalent in grasslands, gardens, farms, ponds and lake littoral zones on both of the islands. On both islands, with the exception of Agasicles hygrophila (the only specialist agent introduced to China for the biocontrol of A. philoxeroides from its original range), the native insects Atractomorpha sinensis, the larvae of Cassida nebulosa, Hymenia recurvalis, Pieris rapae as well as some aphids and spiders feed on A. philoxeroides.
